titleproper.value:
Guide to the John Illo Photograph Collection
                    <lb/> circa 1934-1950s
                    <lb/>
                    <num>PR 358</num>

author.value: Finding aid prepared by Joseph Ditta

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2018-04-03T10:33-0400</date>

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value:
118 photographs taken by John Illo (b. 1926), mostly of ships and tugboats in New York Harbor (with 12 not by him of the wrecked ocean liner 
                <emph render="italic">Morro Castle</emph> near Asbury Park, New Jersey, around 1934). Includes views of Manhattan landmarks like the Chrysler Building and McSorley's Old Ale House, and “characters” encountered on the streets of the city, like a three-card monte dealer, homeless men asleep, gentlemen riding the subway, and a man fishing treasure from a sidewalk grate.

p.value: Photocopying undertaken by staff only. Limited to twenty exposures of stable, unbound material per day. (Researchers may not accrue unused copy amounts from previous days.)

This collection should be cited as the 
                <emph render="boldunderline">John Illo Photograph Collection, PR-358, Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections, The New-York Historical Society</emph>.

New York City native and World War II veteran John Peter Illo (b. 1926) is a graduate of Fordham University and Columbia University (MA and PhD). Now retired, Illo was a professor of English at Shippensburg University in Shippensburg, Pennsylvania.
<emph render="boldunderline">People</emph>: Random "characters" Illo encountered on the streets of Manhattan (see the container list for descriptions). None of the prints are dated.

subject.value: McSorley’s Old Ale House (New York, N.Y.)
Street photography -- New York (State) -- New York

dsc.value:
Ships and waterfront (70 prints) 1 ca. 1934-1950s Scope and Contents

Ships in and around New York Harbor, many unidentified, but some with visible names, such as: African Prince; Ariosa of New York (tug) [photographed 1950]; Domfront; Esso Tug No. 3, Wilmington, Delaware (tug); Helen Buchanan (tug); Heredia, New York [photographed 1949]; Mauretania; Morro Castle [as wrecked near Asbury Park, N.J., in 1934]; Queen Elizabeth; Revere (tug); Santa Clara; Santa Sofia; and W. F. Dalzell (tug). Includes general views of the harbor, Manhattan docks, and infrastructure.

 New York City scenes (28 prints) 2 ca. 1940s-1950s Scope and Contents

General views of Manhattan, with shots of several specific locations, such as the Chrysler Building, Grace Church (802 Broadway), McSorley's Old Ale House (15 East 7th Street), and the New York Public Library (Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street). Includes images of a few businesses as well: Feder's Grocery, Frank Moy Hand Laundry, and the shelves in an unidentified antique shop, photographed 19 December 1947.

 People (20 prints) 3 ca. 1940s-1950s Scope and Contents

Includes photographs of random "characters" Illo encountered around Manhattan, like a barber waiting for customers, homeless men asleep, children burning rubbish, a man fishing treasure from a sidewalk grate, a three-card monte dealer, men riding the subway, and a police officer issuing a ticket to an African-American deliveryman near the Marlboro Cafeteria (1359 Broadway).
